WRITING.TEXT: I did watch the video, but i also read the wikipedia article right after watching it which says it was hit with 22 hellfires during the test. A frigate can certainly be sunk with 22 hellfires, remember that this was an unmanned target ship, so the damage control systems are limited.

Here is [a video that NASA released with details on when Cassini directly passed through the Enceladus plumes.](https://youtu.be/1pspud5eFY0) Cassini was only 30 miles above the surface of Enceladus when it passed through the plumes.

[NASA has been searching for evidence of extraterrestrials for a very long time, and has publicly laid out evidence supporting their existance in the past.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bPMc2RQ--t0) I would suspect that if it were alien life, NASA would be pumping the conference to no end.

[Here's a video of ISS astronauts going inside of it for the first time.](https://www.youtube.com/edit?o=U video_id=3uE0ISlYhHQ) For those who don't know, BEAM is an experimental inflatable habitate which was placed at the ISS by Bigelow Aerospace to test their inflatable space station tech. As far as i know, Bigelow was trying to convince NASA to ultilize the BEAM module more often than just the handful of tests originally planned but as far as i know nothing more has happened.

[Magnetic fields are so good at protecting life from space-born radiation, that NASA is looking into developing artificial electro-magnetic fields for manned spacecraft to protect them on deep space flights.](https://www.youtube.com/edit?o=U video_id=WquNg3k_hiA) Without a magnetic field, a planet or moon would need a very thick atmosphere to block out harmful radiation. If its within the habitable zone, i imagine that such a thick atmosphere would produce a runaway global greenhouse effect like on Venus. If its out past the habitable zone, water would be too cold to liquify on the surface like on Titan.

WRITING.TITLE: Exo-Earths With Global Magnetic Fields Most Likely To Have Life

WRITING.TEXT: If he wants to watch something similar, i would recomend Record of Lodoss War. Its a medival fantasy anime, without the rape and nudity. It does have violence in it so it might not be for a 7 year old, though not the level of gore that Berserk does. There also other classic sword and sorcery type stuff out there thats more kid friendly like movie the Black Cauldron (there is a demon and some undead beasts in this), the Disney movie the Sword in the Stone, or the old disney TV show Gummy Bears for instance.
I said "proven", show me another place in the universe where life had been proven to persist in the long term.

[The amazing thing about the Voyager probes is that they are still operating and producing useful data, even though they have passed the heliopause.](https://youtu.be/r9ifp-BThTE) Given that they are the furthest man made objects from earth, they represent the very frontier of human civilization. Nothing beyond it has ever been touched by anything from human culture. I love the fact that the golden records are attached to the voyager probes, because to me its sort of like the entirety of human culture is spreading further and further outward as the travel.

I would wager that .3 G would have little long term impact on the physiology human body, as long as there is sufficent gravity that the body can tell which way is up and which way is down i imagine it would develop properly. What exactly that lower limit is where problems start to occur is a question that will need to be solved eventually though. I imagine that there might be major problems that could occur on very small asteroids which have practically no gravity.

WRITING.TITLE: Asteroid 2014 JO25 will make a close flyby of Earth on April 19th and should be observable with 8 inch telescopes

WRITING.TEXT: By far [the most impressive thing i think that Cassini has shown us so far has been the footage of the giant rotating hexigon at Saturn's north pole.](https://youtu.be/zVScPy-fiGM) Its amazing to me that something so huge yet so intricate can be maintained on a permanent basis.

[Despite all of the speculation and conjecture over the years, the Earth is still the only place in the Universe where life has been proven to persist in the long term](https://youtu.be/bPMc2RQ--t0), but i imagine that humanity is resilant enough to make it on other worlds. [NASA has been developing plans to colonize space since the 1960's. Its not a matter of if it will happen but when.](https://youtu.be/UcO_BjXfhhc) If humanity is to survive in the very long term if will eventually have to branch out into space for one reason or another. At the same time though, the Earth is where humans are best suited to live so it would be wise to keep the Earth in a happy-healthy state as long as scentifically possible. If we ever do want to move out and live amongst the stars, we need to be sure that we keep the Earth tidy and in good working order so as to ensure that Humanity at the very least survives long enough to reach those other worlds.

WRITING.TITLE: USS Rentz Breaks Apart and Sinks After Taking 22 Hellfire Missile Hits During Exercise Valiant Shield 2016 SINKEX

WRITING.TEXT: Technically there is nothing under current international legal framework to prohibit a colony from declaring itself sovereign. There is also nothing under international law which prohibits a corporation or other non-state entity from claiming ownership over territory on the moon or other celestial bodies.
Its a damn good show

"Shooting tea back into orbit" Quote of the day right there, i'd give you some gold but i'm to cheap. So [have yourself a Michelob Light](https://youtu.be/IdbMcfS9TIw) instead, which is kinda gold coloured i guess lol.
He also killed off the Vietnam War, so i guess not all of the things he killed off were bad though lol

If a nation has an ability to exploit a resource, they will do so regardless of whatever international framework is established, expecially if there is no enforcement mechanism for the framework (as i said, there are no space police). And there were various "forums" as you would call them which determined when various borders were carved up. Most notably the [Paris Peace Conference of 1919](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919), the [Congress of Vienna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna), the [Berlin Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Conference), ect.

[Here's what NASA envisioned the final version of the ARM mission would look like. It originally was to be a manned mission to a near earth asteroid, but NASA figured out that it wouldn't be able to accomplish such a mission within the timeframe that the government wanted.](https://youtu.be/uEtbWbwHiro) There was a law passed that stated that NASA legally had to have a mission to a manned asteroid, so NASA figured a workaround by planning a mission to move an asteroid to Lunar orbit. However, they found out that they couldnt do that either, so they dumbed down the mission to simply pluck a boulder and move it to Earth orbit which led to its unpopularity and ultimate demise since it was but a shadow of the glorious daring mission that was originally planned.

[JPl also produced this projected trajectory animation showing the Asteroids flyby of Earth.](https://youtu.be/ulPxwcxQhV4) Its going to stay well clear of Lunar orbit but still should be visible with small telescopes due to its brightness.

Eventually, once celestial bodies have been fully colonized, like Mars or Ceres for instance, it will be hard to argue that the people who are on Earth have anything to say about what should happen on a planet they don't even live on. Such a quandry is being fleshed out on the SyFy TV show "The Expanse" which I highly recommend to anyone who hasn't seen it.

Those nations that fail to develop manned space programs will likely to have little to say in the matter. I imagine its one reason why India has continued to develop its manned space program despite the immense cost involved. Its hard to for a country to argue that it should have a say if it isn't even involved in the activity in question in the first place.
Well there is an increased cost in landing cargo and people on the surface of the moon vrs putting them into orbit around the moon or one of its Lagrange points.

Who's gonna stop you? The moon police? The international legal framework surrounding space travel prohibits countries from claiming soveriegnty over celestial bodies such as the moon, but it says absolutely nothing regarding the ownership of mined materials ect. There have even been cases in the United States involving the ownership of moon rocks, which indicate that one can claim legal title to resources recovered from a celestial body like the moon in the same manner as one can from unclaimed areas of the earth like oil and fish from international waters of the ocean for example.

WRITING.TITLE: Asteroid to Fly Safely Past Earth on April 19

WRITING.TEXT: There is a decent Uranium deposit located at Copernicus crater, and technology has advanced far enough here on earth that Uranium can be processed out of even very poor concentrations.

[Here's an animation produced by NASA showing its trajectory for the flyby, while from a relative point of view it comes pretty close to Earth](https://youtu.be/ulPxwcxQhV4?t=5), its actually quite some distance from the earth and doesnt even pass within the moon's orbit.

Another benefit that could come from developing lunar infrastructure, ultilizing lunar uranium for Nuclear Pulse propulsion and RTG systems mitigating any threat (or arguement of such a threat) to the Earth

From a technical point of view, [a photonic propulsion system could in theory get a ship to Mars in about three days](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kBHQcArA1fM), but the power required would be immense. The most feasible fast propulsion system for getting manned humans to mars would be a nuclear pulse propulsion system, but there is a very negative public opinion about anything using nuclear explosions so reseach on that method has been practically nil in recent times.

NASA had proposed [a Venus flyby mission planned in the late 1960's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manned_Venus_Flyby) as a follow up to the Apollo moon program, it was abandoned along with most of the other parts of the Apollo applications program by the Nixon administration as part of decreases in NASA's budget.

There have been planned [manned Mars missions by NASA back to the 1960's that were ultimately canceled. In the 1960's there was the NERVA](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b18HtG0DOCM) program, which was ultimately canceled in favor of developing the Space Shuttle. [Then in the 1990's there were the design reference missions](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9xpja3jsYO8) which were canceled in favor of the ISS. Part of the problem that has plagued NASA since the Apollo program ended has been changing priorities with each new administration. There hasn't been a stable space policy for decades, its a major advantage the Chinese space program has since the policy of its program will remain politically stable for decades at a time.

[In the 1960's NASA also had plans to build space stations near the moon, they were to use Lunar sourced material for their construction and serve as space colonies.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UcO_BjXfhhc) I imagine that if the Deep Space Gateway is successful it may spur some further development of lunar infrastructure in which case ultilizing lunar material may be key towards supporting said infrastructure.

WRITING.TITLE: Trajectory Animation of Asteroid 2014 JO25's Flyby of Earth on April 19, 2017

WRITING.TEXT: Well, there has been some real progress made recently with enhancing the efficency of the electromagnetic confinement systems required to keep the fusion reaction going. Much of the progress made recently has been in places like South Korea, where a fusion research reactor there broke a preformance record on a Tokamak there back in December.
